This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2). This award is made as part of the FY 2022 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist.

The title of the project for this fellowship to Samuel Baugh is "Bayesian Detection and Attribution of Athropogenic Influences on Changes in Local Climate Extremes." The host institution for the fellowship is Lawrence Berkeley National Lab, and the sponsoring scientist is Mark	Risser.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

1. While global-scale studies of climate change are crucial for understanding how to address this important problem, the impacts of damaging climate-related events such as heat waves and hurricanes are most immediately felt at the local level. For the purpose of assessing responsibility for damages, as well as quantifying the financial benefits of climate mitigation, it is necessary to calculate precisely the extent to which local-level climate impacts are caused by human activities rather than natural processes. Existing methods for performing these assessments have proven valuable for addressing these problems, however, such methods frequently address climate change at either a global scale or a local scale. This has resulted in local-scale conclusions with a lower statistical power than necessary given the substantial amount of information present in the global system.

The goal of this project was to address this need through the development of a Bayesian hierarchical model that unifies global and local approaches to climate change detection and attribution. By advancing statistical techniques to account for the global climate system’s spatial and temporal correlation patterns, this new method quantifies the connection between human activities and local-scale climate changes with greater precision and robustness than previous approaches. One core methodological innovation of this project included modeling the many sources of uncertainty involved in this problem, including uncertainty from observational data, from the climate model simulations, and from the complexity of the statistical model itself. This approach allows for the method to report uncertainty bounds more reliably while also leveraging the global correlation structure to refine those bounds. A second major innovation was the creation of a flexible spatial model to represent the complex covariance structure of the global climate system, which improves local climate inferences. As these statistical problems are not unique to climate science, these statistical innovations are anticipated to have many promising applications in other inter-disciplinary subject areas.

The developed statistical method was validated by using climate model simulations from the 6th Climate Model Intercomparison Project (CMIP6) to assess the method's accuracy in the scenario where the underlying truth is assumed to be known. The results of this validation study show that the developed method can estimate the contribution of human activities to climate change at specific locations with uncertainty ranges that more comprehensively reflect the underlying sources of uncertainty than previous methods. The application of the method to real-world temperature data demonstrates that it produces results with greater statistical certainty than previously established methods, offering a more reliable tool for local-scale climate assessment.

Beyond the development and validation of the Bayesian model, broader impacts of this project include the establishment of interdisciplinary collaborations and channels of communication between climate science practitioners and statisticians. This work took place at Lawrence Berkeley National Lab and University of California, Berkeley,  where the project was developed in collaboration with statisticians and climate scientists at both institutions. A further outcome of this project was the creation of a climate statistics reading group at Lawrence Berkeley National Lab. This group fostered dialogue between statisticians and climate scientists, addressing a critical need for enhanced collaboration between these disciplines when addressing the impacts of climate change.

The outcomes of this project were shared at both national and international conferences in both statistics and climate science. These have included, among others, the IPCC International Detection and Attribution Group meeting, the International Indian Statistical Association Conference, and the 2023 Joint Statistical Meetings in Toronto. These presentations helped to enhance the relevance and applicability of the method from the perspective of climate science practitioners. Additionally, this exposure has led to ongoing interdisciplinary collaborations for extending and applying this work to real-world climate change assessment projects.   Overall, this project has and will continue to advance research in both statistics and climate science towards understanding the important problem of global climate change and its local-level impacts.
